I'm making this comment after reading the updated documentation (and without having yet looked at the implementation).

So: I don't yet understand this point. By "dbus name" are you referring to the well-known DBus connection name? We can claim multiple well-known names in the one process. This behaviour is explicitly called out in the DBus specification:

> Object paths are often namespaced by starting with a reversed domain name and containing an interface version number, in the same way as interface names and well-known bus names. This makes it possible to implement more than one service, or more than one version of a service, in the same process, even if the services share a connection but cannot otherwise co-operate (for instance, if they are implemented by different plugins). 

https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html#message-protocol-marshaling-object-path

It feels to me like we'd remove a lot of complexity by using one server process per (muxed) TTY. For proposed control semantics, perhaps we could do "most recent client wins" as a means to switch the mux, with all existing clients then disconnected, the mux switched, and then the new client accepted (whether that meets other non-functional requirements needs discussion).

Sorry, quoted the wrong part of the DBus spec there (grabbed the bit about object paths instead of connection names). This seems like a better fit for my intent:

> Connections have one or more bus names associated with them.
>
> ...
>
>  As with interface names, including a version number in well-known bus names is a good idea; it's possible to have the well-known bus name for more than one version simultaneously if backwards compatibility is required.

https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html#message-protocol-names-bus

But together I think they illustrate that it's feasible to achieve this in the one process.

Agreed, it's feasible to achieve in one process, it would require some changes.

- configuration to specify multiple console-ids. Currently there is the
  '--console-id' flag which is used, and will be incompatible when configuring
  multiple consoles behind a mux.

- 'logfile', and other configuration option will be unusable
  with multiple consoles.
  The configuration will have to be change into passing multiple 
  configuration files to the obmc-console-server, one for each console.

- There will have to be a new 'layer' in the data structure for the console-server.
  Multiple 'struct console' may then be part of a 'struct console_server'. This
  may touch large parts of the codebase. Some members of 'struct console' such as 
  the tty device fd may need to go into the new 'struct console_server'.

  Alternatively 'struct console' may have a member 'struct console_server**'
  which would then have members for the 'char* console_id' and the  
  mux configuration.

Inside one process, the gpio control will be easier and there will be no need to release the gpios.

Also there will be no need to explicitly configure the conflicting consoles, since the obmc-console-server will be aware of them all.

Hello! I see that you had proposed a design earlier this month and made some iterations, but received no feedback. I'm not sure why this change didn't appear on my radar, but apologies for reviewing a little late.

I have some questions about the overall design and if we resolve to go in that direction will unfortunately impact the implementation.

I think this needs some substantiation. Some concerns about doing it in the kernel spring to mind, but I think it would be worth enumerating your concerns explicitly so we can be confident in the choice of trade-offs.

There is two concerns for a kernel implementation:

- it will be slow to get something merged
- the actual hardware may not be able to be represented in devicetree form

I don't have the schematics for the system this is for, but let's say it's
a multi-host blade server and blades can be removed. There may be a uart-mux on a blade. So the access to the uart-mux may be cut off.

Since devicetree can only represent the static hardware, it is not suitable for this configuration, and there will be a mismatch with what the kernel thinks there is and what's actually there.

If it were a static system with everything fixed in place then something like
a "uart-mux-gpio" devicetree node may be appropriate. 

But even then there would be additional concerns about how to handle a change in mux state, and how to notify the processes using the virtual uart of this change.

When a userspace implementation is already present, it becomes easier to then later reference that and point to an actual use-case when someone wants to do a kernel based implementation.
Can you massage these arguments into the document as well?

It's great that you have split this up from the original series, but this particular change is still where 90% of the complexity still lies.

I'd suggest that the aim would be to split the _complexity_ between patches in the series, rather than aiming for splitting the _size_ of those changes. Those are typically correlated, but not always.

For example, no need to put the documentation as the last patch - it's perfectly fine to document things as you add them (in fact, it really helps with review if you document as you go). Then you can update those docs as you add more stuff.

For this patch in the series, there's still a lot happening here:

 - you're adding header files for every handler, and changing the mechanism in which those handlers are initialised (why?)
 
 - you're introducing exit-on-sigint behaviour

 - made some things const
 
 - changed the scope of existing variables
 
All of these may well be useful, but are unrelated to the core of your change here (ie., adding multiplexer support). Having those as separate things will definitely make it more clear about how you're intending to implement the mux support, and for us to review and merge these changes.

So, I would suggest pulling those into separate changes that implement one concept -  as much as is sensible. There's a bit of elaboration about that at https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#organizing-commits

From what I can extract from the actual multiplexer-related changes, this is what seems to be happening:
 
  1. you've split `struct console` into `struct console` and `struct console_server`. I assume there's one of the latter, and then one of the former for each muxed console
  
  2. changed the configuration mechanism from reading a single file to reading multiple files from a directory, with each configuring one of the `struct console`s above.
  
  3. added a pointer from the `struct console_server` to the currently-active `struct console`
  
  4. added a new dbus interface that can be used to update this pointer, and perform activation-related operations (printing the log and updating gpios)
  
  5. split the console_run to perform each iteration in a separate function
  

Those all make fairly logical sense, but we can probably split out a lot of the prerequisite infrastructure before adding the actual multiplexing; I imagine that may be quite small in the end.

Foe example, just doing (1) in a single change (but still temporarily assuming a single `struct console`) would make things much more clear, as there would be a lot of churn contained into a technically-trivial patch.

There's a few concepts that I would suggest looking into at an initial review:

  - Using multiple config files seems a bit unwieldy. Can we stay with the single file and just add the necessary structure to represent the mux control? Say, a [section]-based approach for each mux port?
  
  this would help to distinguish configuration that may be common across both consoles too.
  
  - it's assuming a 0/1 single-gpio-driven mux at the moment. I know this is the only implementation at present, but we may want to abstract this a little for alternatives (eg., there are parts that have two GPIOs that select between four uarts). While we don't want to design too far ahead, maybe just abstracting this into something like a `console_mux_select()`, that defers to our single gpio implementation for now.
 
I've put a few comments inline, but they may be less relevant depending on whether you make structural changes, so don't worry too much about addressing each of them at the moment - they're mainly pointers for future items.

A couple of things in general though:

 - if you're adding new files, please include the copyright header too
 
 - your new header files seem to have a lot of unnecessary `#includes`
 
 - you have quite a few of
 
```

    printf(...)
}
```

   a helper function or macro may neaten this up a bit; say:
    
    
```
static void cs_debug(struct console_server *cs, const char *fmt, ...);
```

OK, so it sounds like the underlying requirement here is that you're able to have *multiple instances* of a handler, rather than anything around how the handlers are defined.

In order to do that, I'd propose that we split the handler definitions from the handler instances. ie., `struct handler->init` would return a new instance of the handler, rather than populating the (static) `struct handler`. the struct handler just becomes only the per-handler data, consisting of ops and a name.

The separate section is just so we can build our handlers set at link-time, that's all; we could certainly do the same by exporting (just) the `struct handler` from each and putting those in an array and have that defined a build-time instead. However, this is pretty orthogonal to your goal of having multiple instances active - and certainly doesn't mean we need to create headers and expose internals for every handler.

The link-time trick is tidy and I'd prefer to keep it given it's what we already have.

I think that addressing Jeremy's concerns would shave complexity from the patch (with the reduction in type exposure and header files). Reducing or isolating the complexity will help a lot with the review process.

No need to test if the pointer is `NULL` before `free()` - `free()`'s contract is that it will not misbehave if the pointer is `NULL`:

> The free() function frees the memory space pointed to by ptr,
> which must have been returned by a previous call to malloc() or
> related functions.  Otherwise, or if ptr has already been freed,
> undefined behavior occurs.  **If ptr is NULL, no operation is
> performed.**

https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/free.3.html
